block.p: Challenger to Ruling Party In Mexico Wins Presidency Vicente Fox Quesada, the rough-spoken rancher and businessman who galvanized a maverick grass-roots presidential campaign, scored a momentous victory in Mexico's presidential election, ousting the political party that has ruled for 71 years. President Ernesto Zedillo conceded that his Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, had lost.

Challenger to Ruling Party In Mexico Wins Presidency Vicente Fox Quesada, the rough-spoken rancher and businessman who galvanized a maverick grass-roots presidential campaign, scored a momentous victory in Mexico's presidential election, ousting the political party that has ruled for 71 years. President Ernesto Zedillo conceded that his Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, had lost.
Many Mexicans who live in the United States returned to their country to vote, crossing south over the border from as far away as San Francisco, Washington and Chicago.

Uganda 'No Party' System Vote Voters overwhelmingly endorsed Uganda's ''no-party'' political system, according to final results, though only half of registered voters went to the polls. Leaders of Uganda and neighboring Rwanda met over the weekend to defuse tensions over their role in the fighting in Congo.

Israeli Dispute Over Trees The Jewish National Fund in Israel, whose tree-planting program long epitomized the Zionist enterprise in its ambition to make the desert bloom, has been accused of uprooting saplings planted by tourists to make way for the next day's busloads. It set up a committee to investigate.

10 Saved From Indonesia Ferry After nearly three days spent clinging to debris, 10 people were rescued from a passenger ferry crammed with nearly 500 people that sank off an Indonesian island last week, officials said. More than 480 passengers are still missing.

Criticism of Iraq Policy The Clinton administration's failure to act on its pledge to support the fractious, far-flung opponents of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has prompted growing criticism from Republicans in Congress, who used a visit to Washington by Iraqi opposition leaders to intensify attacks on the administration's policy toward Iraq.

Scott Ritter, the former United Nations arms inspector who quit two years ago charging that Secretary General Kofi Annan and American officials were undercutting efforts to disarm President Hussein, now says the Iraqis have no prohibited weapons of any importance left.

Albright Focusing on Legacy As Madeleine K. Albright shuttled from region to region last week, the question of what legacy she will leave as secretary of state was never far away. One thing is clear: in the last six months of her term, she wants to concentrate on her vision of democracy.

Mongolia Votes for Parliament Election results trickled in from Mongolia's parliamentary elections yesterday, with the nation's resurgent former Communists expecting to make strong gains. An American group observing the vote confirmed that at least two candidates of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party -- the former Communists -- had won in the capital.

Miles to Go in Campaign, Amid Gloom and Confidence It is no secret that even with 130 days to go before the election, Democrats are unsettled, even gloomy, while Republicans are confident. Could the presidential race be over barely after it started? One national poll had Vice President Al Gore 13 points behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. But even Bush loyalists concede that Democrats should not despair -- at least not yet.

Former Incumbents Seek Seats In the battle for control of Congress, three of the most hotly contested House races this year involve former incumbents who quit to run unsuccessfully for other offices and are trying to reclaim their old seats.

Religion in the Classroom? Close on the heels of the Supreme Court's latest ruling against officially sponsored prayer at public schools, the Colorado State Board of Education is expected, on Thursday, to pass a resolution on that encourages public schools to display the national motto ''In God we trust.'' The effort has drawn criticism as yet another attempt to bring religion into the classroom in Colorado.

Only 2 Names on Reform Ballot When the balloting begins on Wednesday in the Reform Party presidential primary, voters will have only two choices: Patrick J. Buchanan, the former conservative television commentator, and John Hagelin, a physicist.

Pressure at an Early Age Higher education has become a preoccupation for children even before they reach puberty, with many sixth graders driven to excel by parents who had seized on test scores and early college readiness as new benchmarks for success.

Another Year of High School The president of the American Federation of Teachers plans to propose today that schools add an optional fifth year to high school to help students meet academic standards required for a diploma. In her speech as the union opens its biennial convention in Philadelphia, Sandra Feldman, the group's president, will call for a ''transitional-year'' program, either before ninth grade or in high school, in which adult-literacy specialists would help teenagers lacking basic skills catch up so they could confront more challenging course work.

The Wolf's Endangered Status The federal government is preparing to announce that the gray wolf, which was once nearly shot, trapped and poisoned out of existence in the lower 48 states, is abundant enough in a few places in its range that it no longer uniformly needs the strict protection afforded the country's most endangered species.

A Plucky Participant In the Parade of Sail Tomorrow's grand Parade of Sail through New York Harbor will feature hundreds of the most imposing vessels on the planet. And then there is the Bat'kivshchyna, the official, if utterly broke, representative of Ukraine, and a floating testament to either the indomitability of the human spirit or the primacy of Murphy's Law.

Teachers Meet Computers Thousands of educators around the country with computers in their classrooms are using their time off this summer to confront what they see as their greatest deficiency: technology literacy.

3 Dead in Murder-Suicide A Jersey City man apparently distraught over a custody battle killed his two young sons in their bed, then killed himself, prosecutors said. His estranged wife found the bodies.

The Harry Potter Phenomenon By all accounts there will be tens of thousands of sleepless children and parents -- perhaps many more -- showing up in bookstores late Friday night to snap up ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' when it officially goes on sale at 12:01 a.m. Saturday. The children's book, the latest in the wildly popular series by J. K. Rowling, is already a publishing phenomenon, fueled by a shrewd marketing campaign by Scholastic.

Inquiry Casts a Shadow As collectors and dealers gathered in London last week for Christie's and Sotheby's big sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art, the auction houses' legal troubles in the United States seemed to make no difference to the buyers. Still, it was clear that the shadow cast by the federal antitrust investigation in New York had crossed the Atlantic.

Begay Wins Back-to-Back Notah Begay III won the Greater Hartford Open with a dramatic 23-foot birdie putt at the 18th hole, becoming the first player on the PGA Tour to win tournaments in consecutive weeks this year.
France Wins Euro 2000 France, the 1998 World Cup champion, defeated Italy, 2-1, 13 minutes into overtime, in the European Championship soccer final in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
Rolf Magener A German business executive and writer known for his wartime escape from a remote British internment camp in India, he was 89.
Haskell Cohen A longtime publicity director for the National Basketball Association who helped create the league's All-Star Game, he was 86.

Oil Consultant Faces Inquiry Federal prosecutors are investigating whether an American trade consultant funneled millions of dollars in payments from major oil companies to Kazakhstan officials who are his clients, according to a Justice Department document.

A Team of 3 Leads Oracle After the abrupt resignation of Oracle's president, Raymond J. Lane, the day-to-day operation of the software giant is now in the hands of a troika of executives who report directly to Lawrence J. Ellison, the company's flamboyant and mercurial founder and chief executive.

Concern Over Chinese Dot-Com The poor debut on Friday of the Chinese Internet company Netease.com on the Nasdaq market has sent shudders through China's young Internet entrepreneurs, many of whom see an overseas listing as their only hope of survival.

Telefonica Tightens Grip Telefonica S.A., Spain's largest phone operator, has increased control of its Argentine and Brazilian units after a majority of investors swapped their stock in the units for the company's shares.
Merger Talks at Dresdner Executives of Dresdner Bank plan to discuss merging with Commerzbank to form Germany's second-largest bank at a meeting in Frankfurt tomorrow.
U.S. Markets to Close Early The stock market and other financial markets will close at 1 p.m. today and will be closed tomorrow in observance of the Fourth of July.
